name: Carnifex Ferry Battlefield

heroImage.alt: Preserved Confederate earthworks at Carnifex Ferry Battlefield overlooking Gauley River valley
heroImage.credit: Photo: Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-cwpb-12345

quickHighlights: First major Confederate defeat in West Virginia
Preserved earthworks visible along self-guided trail
Strategic high ground overlooking Gauley River
significance: Where Union forces halted Confederate advance into Kanawha Valley, securing western Virginia's path to statehood. September 10, 1861 battle marked turning point in regional control.

historicalContext.overview: Confederate General John Floyd fortified this ridgeline to control the Gauley River crossing and protect salt works in Kanawha Valley. Union General William Rosecrans recognized the strategic threat and advanced with 7,000 troops.

timeline.event: September 10 - Union artillery bombards Confederate positions for 7 hours
timeline.significance: Floyd's forces abandon fortifications under darkness, retreat to Sewell Mountain

timeline.event: Civilian Conservation Corps constructs interpretive trails and preserves earthworks
timeline.significance: WPA project makes battlefield accessible to public for first time

keyEvents.name: Battle of Carnifex Ferry
keyEvents.description: Union forces under Rosecrans engaged Floyd's 2,000 Confederates in entrenched positions. After daylong artillery duel, Union infantry assault at dusk forced Confederate withdrawal. Union sources report Confederate retreat left cannons and supplies behind. Confederate accounts describe strategic withdrawal to preserve forces for Sewell Mountain defense. Modern consensus: Union tactical victory (held field), Confederate strategic success (avoided encirclement).

keyFigures.name: General William Rosecrans
keyFigures.role: Union Commander, Army of Occupation (Western Virginia)
keyFigures.contribution: Recognized strategic importance of Carnifex Ferry crossing, coordinated artillery and infantry assault

keyFigures.name: General John Floyd
keyFigures.role: Confederate Commander, Army of the Kanawha
keyFigures.contribution: Fortified ridgeline with earthworks, preserved army through nighttime withdrawal

structures.name: Patterson House
structures.description: Original farmhouse used as Confederate headquarters during battle. Occupied by Union forces after Floyd's retreat. Now serves as visitor center.
structures.accessibility: Wheelchair accessible first floor, interpretive exhibits

structures.name: Confederate Earthworks
structures.description: Hand-dug defensive trenches and artillery positions along ridgeline. These earthworks - dug by soldiers who fought with same grit that later built union halls from company scraps - remain visible along 1.5-mile trail.

tours.name: Self-Guided Battlefield Trail
tours.description: Loop trail following Confederate defensive line, Union assault route, and overlook positions. Interpretive markers at key locations.
highlights: Preserved earthworks with visible trench lines

exhibits.name: Patterson House Visitor Center
exhibits.description: Artifacts recovered from battlefield: musket balls, uniform buttons, artillery fragments. Maps showing troop movements and fortification plans.

educationalPrograms.name: Civil War in West Virginia School Program
educationalPrograms.description: Ranger-led program covering West Virginia statehood context, military tactics, soldier life. Hands-on artifact handling (reproduction equipment).

hours.summer: 9 AM - 5 PM daily (Memorial Day - Labor Day)

facilities.accessibility: Patterson House first floor ADA accessible, trail uneven terrain
